conclusion: Understanding the problem involves two velocity-time graphs for objects A and B.
In a velocity-time graph, the x-axis is time and the y-axis is velocity; the slope represents acceleration.
Both objects start at time t=0 with zero velocity and reach zero velocity again at time t1.
Object A has a higher peak velocity compared to object B.
The shapes of the curves suggest both objects are accelerating and then decelerating, following a parabolic path.
Difference in speed Δv = v_A - v_B.
At t=0, both velocities are zero, so the difference is zero.
As time increases, v_A increases faster than v_B, so Δv increases.
At some point, Δv reaches a maximum and then decreases as time approaches t1.
The difference in speed is not continuously increasing; it increases to a maximum and then decreases.
Velocities can be described by quadratic functions of time.
Δv(t) = (a - c)*t - (b - d)*t^2 is a quadratic function in t.
To find the maximum of Δv, set d(Δv)/dt = 0 and solve for t.
The time at which the difference in velocity is maximum is t = (a - c)/(2*(b - d)).
Before this time, Δv increases, and after this time, Δv decreases.
Considering relative acceleration, both objects have similar acceleration-deceleration patterns.
The difference in velocity follows a similar pattern to the velocity curves.
The difference in speed between the two objects is not continuously increasing.
Final answer: No, the difference in speed is not continuously increasing.
